article.title: Geoffrey Hinton says people understand very little about how LLMs actually work, so they still think LLMs are very different from us - "but actually, it's very important for people to understand that they're very like us." LLMs don’t just generate words, but also meaning.
article.content: Go to artificialr/artificialr/artificialReddit’s home for Artificial Intelligence (AI)MembersOnline•MetaKnowingTop 1% PosterGeoffrey Hinton says people understand very little about how LLMs actually work, so they still think LLMs are very different from us - "but actually, it's very important for people to understand that they're very like us." LLMs don’t just generate words, but also meaning.MediaShareShare

tweet_data.tweet:
📈📊 Hinton argues LLMs like Meta's *do* grasp meaning, challenging prior beliefs. This shift suggests AI understands concepts more like humans than we thought. Reddit discussions will be interesting! #AI #Tech #LLMs #GeoffreyHinton

🔗 https://v.redd.it/j8fc5i7fww6f1

analysis.innovation: Hinton argues that LLMs are more similar to human understanding than previously thought, suggesting they grasp meaning, not just generate words. This challenges the perception of LLMs as purely statistical models.

article.title: 2022 vs 2025 AI-image.
article.content: I was scrolling through old DMs with a friend of mine when I came across an old AI-generated image that we had laughed at, and I decided to regenerate it. AI is laughing at us now 💀

tweet_data.tweet:
⚡🎯 AI image generation leaps forward! 2025 images boast dramatically improved quality compared to 2022. See the stunning visual progress. #AI #Tech #AIImage #AIevolution

🔗 https://i.redd.it/59cs5blyww6f1.jpeg

analysis.innovation: The main innovation is the significant improvement in AI image generation quality between 2022 and 2025. The comparison highlights how much more realistic and sophisticated AI-generated images have become in a relatively short time.

article.title: "Language and Image Minus Cognition." Leif Weatherby on LLMs
article.content: by Robin ManleyLeif Weatherbyis an Associate Professor of German at New York University, where he directs theDigital Theory Lab. Robin Manley spoke with Dr. Weatherby about his latest book,Language Machines: Cultural AI and the End of Remainder Humanism(University of Minnesota Press, 2025), which argues that Large Language Models (LLMs) have effected a separation of cognition from language and computation in a form that corresponds to earlier structuralist theories.Robin Manley:In the introducti...

tweet_data.tweet:
💡🔍 New theory: LLMs decouple language from cognition! Weatherby (NYU/U Minn Press) argues this separation fundamentally changes ho... #AI #Tech #LLMs #ArtificialIntelligence

🔗 https://www.jhiblog.org/2025/06/11/language-and-image-minus-cognition-an-interview-with-leif-weatherby/

analysis.innovation: The main idea presented isn't a technical breakthrough, but a theoretical argument: LLMs have separated language and computation from cognition, echoing earlier structuralist theories. This suggests a fundamental shift in how we understand language and AI.

article.title: Inside the Apollo "8-Ball" FDAI (Flight Director / Attitude Indicator)
article.content: During the Apollo flights to the Moon, the astronauts observed the spacecraft's orientation on a special instrument called the FDAI (Flight Director / Attitude Indicator). This instrument showed the spacecraft's attitude—its orientation—by rotating a ball. This ball was nicknamed the "8-ball" because it was black (albeit only on one side). The instrument also acted as a flight director, using three yellow needles to indicate how the astronauts should maneuver the spacecraft. Three more pointers ...

tweet_data.tweet:
🔍📊 Apollo FDAI's 8-ball visually displayed spacecraft attitude. This intuitive design simplified navigation for astronauts. #AI #Tech #Apollo #Spaceflight

🔗 https://www.righto.com/2025/06/inside-apollo-fdai.html

analysis.innovation: The Apollo FDAI's innovation was visually representing spacecraft attitude (orientation) using a rotating "8-ball" and providing flight direction cues via needles, enabling astronauts to intuitively understand and control the spacecraft's position in space.
companies: No companies are mentioned in the provided text.
